Luigi LENGUITO
Luigi LENGUITO
posts.content:
Today 
hashtag
#CyberTalent spotlight is on Ana Isabel Ayerbe Fern√°ndez-Cuesta

What was your original career path and how did you end up in the cyber security field?

I studied computer science and obtained an MSC in Robotics and Automation, so my original career was oriented towards the industrial application of new technologies. I¬¥ve always been enthusiastic about new technologies and the opportunities they could bring, but at the same
time couldn¬¥t avoid thinking about the potential risks of someone making bad use of them.

‚ÑπÔ∏è What is the most appealing thing to you about working in cyber security?

A feeling of doing something good for society when trying to build new products, services and systems with built-in cyber security or training people to be better prepared to make safe use of the digital systems and services or when trying to stop or minimize the impact of cyber attacks at different levels.

 Name a book/movie that has inspired you. Anything specific to cyber security that you would recommend?

The film ‚ÄúMinority Report‚Äù showed many different aspects of a potential future, with ubiquitous technology taking a lot of decisions on behalf of people. It was a threatening future with many security- and privacy-related issues not well solved. The book ‚Äú1984‚Äù by George Orwell, showing the risks of massive surveillance, has also been an inspiration for me.

 I recommend you to follow her , like and comment on this post to share her example, and perhaps suggest others to showcase !

>>> This profile is part of a series I‚Äôm publishing every other day in collaboration with @Women4Cyber Foundation, follow me to receive the next updates.
posts.commentAdded: Inspiring journey, Ana! Your insights on the importance of cyber security for society resonate deeply. Keep shining in this crucial field! üåü #CyberTalent

posts.name:
Joshua Miller
Joshua Miller
posts.content:
Leading Through Ambiguity: A Masterclass in Adaptive 
hashtag
#Leadership



As a leader, you're often tasked with charting a course through uncharted waters, mobilizing diverse teams, and driving progress in the face of seemingly insurmountable challenges.

In many ways, leading through ambiguity is akin to navigating a maze without a map. You've got a general sense of where you need to go, but the path forward is anything but straightforward.

The true mark of an exceptional leader isn't their ability to predict every twist and turn but rather their capacity to adapt, experiment, and keep their team focused on the end goal.

How effective are you in leading through change? Ask yourself:

‚Ä¢ How do you typically respond when faced with uncertainty or a lack of clear direction as a leader?
‚Ä¢ What strategies do you employ to stay calm, creative, and adaptable in high-pressure situations?
‚Ä¢ How can you cultivate a mindset and culture that embraces ambiguity as an opportunity for growth and innovation?

Regardless of how you answered, here are 3 ways to sharpen your skills and master the art of leading through ambiguity:

1.) Empower Your Team:
Delegate responsibilities and tap your team's diverse talents to tackle challenges.

2.) Keep the Big Picture in Sight:
Maintain a laser-sharp focus on the ultimate end goal to guide decision-making.

3.) Celebrate Small Wins:
Recognize and appreciate the incremental progress you and your team make.

By embracing the chaos, empowering your people, and maintaining a steadfast commitment to your objectives, you can transform even the most daunting leadership challenge into an opportunity to showcase your true adaptability and problem-solving prowess.

Stay inspired, and followfor more.
--
Coaching works; let's work together.
 Book Your Coaching Discovery Session Today:

comments.commentText: We‚Äôre facing more moments where we have to lead through uncertainty. What matters most is staying real, inspiring belief, getting buy-in, focusing, following through, and staying steady. Adaptability keeps things moving, but your North Star and purpose keep you grounded. Stay calm, curious, and open (eg listening) to inspire others along the way.

Fred Leong 100% Leaders now more than ever must possess the skills to be agile while astute, resilient while rational and open while operational. Not an easy nor impossible task but it will require individuals to step up their game if they wish to remain relevant.

Oh man Joshua, ain‚Äôt this the truth. I remember several moments after many years of leading teams where new things came up that I had never experienced before. No matter how experienced you get, you will always be faced with new challenges, it‚Äôs then employing your experience to interpret the path forward.
Kurtis Graham Yes indeed. It's your last sentence that's the keeper. It's entirely in who, how, when, where and why and what that path is interpreted. Thank you for sharing Kurtis!

posts.commentAdded: Great insights on leading through ambiguity! Empowering teams and celebrating small wins are key to navigating uncertainty. #Leadership #Growth

posts.name:
Josh Braun
Josh Braun
posts.content:
‚ÄòCheer up‚Äô never cheers anyone up.

I saw it happen at the UPS store. 

There was a line out the door.
Packages piled up to the ceiling.

A customer was interacting with an employee. The employee looked exhausted.

No smile.
No small talk.
Just trying to get through the day.

The customer, probably trying to be helpful, said:
‚ÄúCheer up!‚Äù

It didn‚Äôt go over well.
The employee rolled his eyes and kept working.

I don‚Äôt think people say this to dismiss someone‚Äôs feelings.

They probably mean well.
Maybe they‚Äôve heard it before and think it helps.

But it doesn‚Äôt.

When someone‚Äôs in a bad mood, the last thing they want is a pep talk.

Nobody feels better because you told them to.

What they really want is to feel understood.

Imagine if the customer had said:
‚ÄúLong day?‚Äù
Or
‚ÄúDealing with Boca people all day? You deserve a medal.‚Äù
Or
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got so much going on, it must feel never-ending.‚Äù

That‚Äôs empathy.
That‚Äôs making someone feel understood.

It‚Äôs the same in sales. It‚Äôs the same in leadership. It‚Äôs the same in life.

You don‚Äôt connect by telling people how to feel.

You connect by showing you understand how they feel.

comments.commentText: Empathy is the real "pick-me-up" - it's difficult to develop though.
Eudes Costa Junior empathy is a skill you can learn. Like piano or painting. No different.
I do believe so too, Josh. But it's very difficult since we are mostly living on auto-mode, not giving ourselves time to reflect. I need to keep reminding myself.

So true!  Sometimes people just want to be seen and heard, not told how to feel. 

A little empathy can go a long way in making meaningful connections, whether in customer service, leadership, or everyday life. 

Instead of offering generic advice, taking a moment to acknowledge someone‚Äôs situation can make all the difference.

What‚Äôs a simple way you show empathy in your daily interactions?

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Empathy is key in building connections. A little understanding goes a long way, both in our personal and professional lives.
